title: Intrinsic priority for language types (e.g. always suggest `markdown` before `julia markdown` when a user is typing `markd...`)

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body: When creating a scratch file I often want to set the language to Markdown, so I run the "Change Language Mode" command and select `markdown`. It's easy with these keystrokes: `F1`, `lang`, `markd`. But sometimes, `julia markdown` shows up at the top of the list, which is annoying and _seems wrong_. Maybe this is my own ignorance, but I don't know who Julia is, and why she has her own version of markdown. I'm joking ofc, but really ... I've never heard of it, and I'd assume that `markdown` is a vastly more popular language than `julia markdown`. So why not have a priority rank on these language suggestions? Perhaps based on a crude "popularity" estimation? Maybe even ranking by leading text matching (given that `markdown` starts with `markd`, whereas `julia markdown` does not?) Anyway, thanks for listening 👍

We could look into command rewriting for this.

title: Fix KaTeX regex to prevent false math detection in PowerShell code
body:
The KaTeX extension was incorrectly interpreting PowerShell variables like `$i = 1;` as math expressions in VS Code's markdown rendering, causing formatting issues in the Chat interface.

![Issue demonstration](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/68135d44-0fe6-45a1-9ae1-4b270fa31a49)

The problem occurred because the `inlineRuleNonStandard` regex pattern was too permissive and didn't properly check for word boundaries around dollar signs. Code like:

```powershell
for ($i = 1; $i -le 20; $i++) { echo "hello world"; Start-Sleep 1 }
```

Would have the `$i` variables incorrectly rendered as mathematical expressions instead of plain code.

## Changes Made

1. **Updated `inlineRuleNonStandard` regex**: Added `(?![a-zA-Z0-9])` negative lookahead to prevent matching when the closing `$` is immediately followed by word or number characters.

2. **Enhanced start method logic**: Added a check to ensure the opening `$` is not immediately preceded by word or number characters using `/[a-zA-Z0-9]/.test(prevChar)`.

3. **Added comprehensive test cases**: Including tests for PowerShell loops, shell variables, and edge cases to ensure the fix works correctly while preserving legitimate math rendering.

## Validation

The fix correctly handles these scenarios:
- ✅ PowerShell variables (`$i`, `$USER`, `$PATH`) no longer trigger math rendering
- ✅ Dollar signs followed by words (`$10dollars`) are treated as plain text
- ✅ All legitimate math expressions (`$\frac{1}{2}$`, `$x^2$`) continue to work
- ✅ Math in parentheses and brackets still renders correctly

Fixes #261440.

title: dont delay explicitly triggered suggestions
Governance controls for MCP related settings
body:
- Crosslinking https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/158987 as I think it was the wrong place 🙇‍♂️ 

We are interested in governance controls for MCP related settings for following reasons:

1) Enterprise Governance what MCP servers and tools are approved, safe and allowed to be used. Be able to give exceptions to certain groups (like MCP server development team) for development.
2) This also helps distributing standard settings so that engineers do not need to add settings or rely on git repository based settings

Ideally this would be GitHub side policies vs vscode org controlled settings as this governance and distribution should work equally for all IDEs. Assuming that MCP capabilities will land in other IDEs as well.

title: Regression: Can no longer start powershell at startup via tasks

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

labels.name: verification-needed
labels.description: Verification of issue is requested

labels.name: regression
labels.description: Something that used to work is now broken

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: Windows 11 24H2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set up a task for the workspace (i.e., in `.vscode/tasks.json`) with the following json.
This is taken directly from [VSCode documentation itself](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/terminal/basics#_automating-terminals-with-tasks).

```jsonc
{
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "presentation": {
    "echo": false,
    "reveal": "always",
    "focus": false,
    "panel": "dedicated",
    "showReuseMessage": true
  },
  "tasks": [
    {
      "label": "Create terminals",
      "dependsOn": [
        "First",
        "Second"
      ],
      // Mark as the default build task so cmd/ctrl+shift+b will create them
      "group": {
        "kind": "build",
        "isDefault": true
      },
      // Try start the task on folder open
      "runOptions": {
        "runOn": "folderOpen"
      }
    },
    {
      // The name that shows up in terminal tab
      "label": "First",
      // The task will launch a shell
      "type": "shell",
      "command": "",
      // Set the shell type
      "options": {
        "shell": {
          "executable": "cmd.exe",
          "args": []
        }
      },
      // Mark as a background task to avoid the spinner animation on the terminal tab
      "isBackground": true,
      "problemMatcher": [],
      // Create the tasks in a terminal group
      "presentation": {
        "group": "my-group"
      }
    },
    {
      "label": "Second",
      "type": "shell",
      "command": "",
      "options": {
        "shell": {
          "executable": "pwsh.exe",
          "args": []
        }
      },
      "isBackground": true,
      "problemMatcher": [],
      "presentation": {
        "group": "my-group"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

2. Restart vscode in the workspace to trigger the task to run.

Before version 1.103.0 it would start powershell as expected.
Since version 1.103.0, the `cmd` task works, but now the `pwsh` task gives an error:
```
 *  Executing task in folder <folder name>:

Processing -File '' failed: The path is empty. (Parameter 'path') Specify a valid path for the -File parameter.

 *  The terminal process "pwsh -nologo """ terminated with exit code: 64. 
 *  Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it. 
```

I suspect, prior to version 1.103.0, the terminal would not send an empty command, whereas now it does.

If this is expected behavior with a workaround, please update the documentation.

title: change setting name to minShowDelay
NES: Debounce fetch based on `minShowDelay` setting

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: NES
labels.description: Issues related to the next edit suggestions feature

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: If a user sets `editor.inlineSuggest.minShowDelay` setting to a large value, then we can try and delay the request to have more time to compute context and reduce the number of requests made to the model. The API now has a `earliestShownDateTime` property which specifies the earliest point in time by which the suggestion will be shown.

Copilot Chat: Support lmstudio (or a generic openai-like API) as Model

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

LMStudio (https://lmstudio.ai) allows local AI model mounting and features an OpenAI-like API (https://lmstudio.ai/docs/app/api). It is notable in that it supports using GPUs (specifically non-CUDA AMD GPUs) out-of-box. 

It would be great to have a feature in the copilot chat manage models, to add either direct LMStudio support (like with Ollama), or a way to support a generic OpenAPI compatible API endpoints, which LMStudio is.

<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: All

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an extension with a Webview containing layered CSS:
```css
@layer extension {
  input:focus {
    outline: none;
  }
}
```
2. Launch the extension and open the Webview
3. Observe that VS Code's default styles override the extension's layered styles

Expected Behavior:

1. Styles declared in `@layer extension` should override VS Code's default styles
2. Extension authors should be able to use CSS layers to organize styles without priority conflicts

Proposed Solution:

1. Wrap default styles in a low-priority layer:
```css
@layer vscode-default {
  /* some default style */
}
```

title: Enhance .env File Management with Integrated Environment Switching and Validation

labels.name: *extension-candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as good extension implementation

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

## Describe the Feature You'd Like

I would like to propose an enhancement to VS Code's `.env` file management capabilities. Currently, managing multiple `.env` files for different environments (e.g., `.env.development`, `.env.production`) can be cumbersome, requiring manual file renaming or complex workarounds.

**Proposed Feature:** Intelligent `.env` File Management with Environment Switching and Validation.

This feature would provide a more integrated and streamlined experience for handling environment-specific configurations.

### Key Components:

1.  **Automatic `.env` Syntax Highlighting:**
    *   **Why:** To improve readability and parseability of `.env` files, which are plain text by default. Proper syntax highlighting makes it easier to distinguish between keys, values, and comments, reducing errors.
    *   **How:** VS Code would automatically detect `.env` files (and variations like `.env.development`) and apply appropriate syntax highlighting, similar to how it handles JSON or YAML files.

2.  **Unified Multi-File `.env` Management Interface:**
    *   **Why:** Developers often use multiple `.env` files for different deployment stages or local configurations. Managing these manually is inefficient and error-prone.
    *   **How:** A dedicated UI panel or explorer view within VS Code would list all detected `.env` files for the current project. This would allow users to see all their configurations at a glance.

3.  **Seamless Environment Switching:**
    *   **Why:** Developers frequently need to switch the active `.env` configuration without performing manual file operations like renaming or copying.
    *   **How:** Users could select an `.env` file from the management interface, and VS Code would dynamically enable that configuration for the project. This could be achieved internally by VS Code managing which `.env` file the application runtime uses, or by providing clear instructions and shortcuts for the user to activate a specific environment.

4.  **Built-in Validation and Conflict Detection:**
    *   **Why:** To catch potential configuration errors early. Duplicate variable definitions across different `.env` files can lead to unexpected behavior.
    *   **How:** The feature would scan all project `.env` files to identify and flag duplicate variable definitions with conflicting values. This proactive error checking ensures greater reliability in application configurations.

### Benefits:

*   **Increased Developer Productivity:** Automates tedious manual tasks related to `.env` file management.
*   **Reduced Configuration Errors:** Catches common mistakes before they impact application behavior.
*   **Improved Readability:** Makes `.env` files easier to understand and work with.
*   **Streamlined Workflow:** Simplifies the process of managing application environments.

This enhancement would make VS Code an even more powerful tool for modern development workflows that heavily rely on environment-specific configurations.

title: Memory Leak in File Search (Ctrl+P) with Large Projects (1M+ Files)

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: windows 11 / Ubuntu 22.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Generate test project using this Python script:
```Python
import os
import random
import string
import argparse
from collections import deque

def generate_random_name(length=20):
    """Generate random filename/directory name (letters and digits)"""
    return ''.join(random.choices(string.ascii_letters + string.digits, k=length))

def generate_project(root_dir, total_files, max_depth=8, dirs_per_level=5, files_per_dir=20):
    """
    Generate test project structure
    :param root_dir: Root directory of the project
    :param total_files: Total number of files to generate
    :param max_depth: Maximum directory depth
    :param dirs_per_level: Number of directories per level
    :param files_per_dir: Files per directory range
    """
    os.makedirs(root_dir, exist_ok=True)
    dir_queue = deque([(root_dir, 0)])  # (current directory, current depth)
    all_dirs = [root_dir]  # Track all created directories
    files_created = 0

    # Phase 1: Create directory structure using BFS
    while dir_queue and files_created < total_files:
        current_dir, current_depth = dir_queue.popleft()
        
        # Create files in current directory
        num_files = min(
            random.randint(0, files_per_dir),
            total_files - files_created
        )
        for _ in range(num_files):
            filename = f"{generate_random_name()}.txt"
            filepath = os.path.join(current_dir, filename)
            open(filepath, 'w').close()
            files_created += 1
        
        # Create subdirectories (if max depth not reached)
        if current_depth < max_depth and files_created < total_files:
            num_subdirs = random.randint(0, dirs_per_level)
            for _ in range(num_subdirs):
                subdir_name = generate_random_name()
                subdir_path = os.path.join(current_dir, subdir_name)
                os.makedirs(subdir_path, exist_ok=True)
                dir_queue.append((subdir_path, current_depth + 1))
                all_dirs.append(subdir_path)
    
    # Phase 2: Add remaining files to existing directories
    while files_created < total_files:
        target_dir = random.choice(all_dirs)
        filename = f"{generate_random_name()}.txt"
        filepath = os.path.join(target_dir, filename)
        open(filepath, 'w').close()
        files_created += 1

if __name__ == "__main__":
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='Generate large-scale test file system')
    parser.add_argument('root', type=str, help='Root directory path')
    parser.add_argument('--files', type=int, required=True, help='Total number of files to generate')
    parser.add_argument('--max_depth', type=int, default=10, help='Maximum directory depth (default: 10)')
    parser.add_argument('--dirs_per_level', type=int, default=8, help='Number of directories per level (default: 0-8)')
    parser.add_argument('--files_per_dir', type=int, default=15, help='Files per directory range (default: 0-15)')
    
    args = parser.parse_args()
    
    print(f"Starting project generation...")
    print(f"Root directory: {args.root}")
    print(f"Target file count: {args.files:,}")
    print(f"Directory depth: {args.max_depth}")
    print(f"Subdirectories per level: 0-{args.dirs_per_level}")
    print(f"Files per directory: 0-{args.files_per_dir}")
    print("=" * 50)
    
    generate_project(
        root_dir=args.root,
        total_files=args.files,
        max_depth=args.max_depth,
        dirs_per_level=args.dirs_per_level,
        files_per_dir=args.files_per_dir
    )
    
    print(f"\nProject generation completed! Created {args.files:,} empty files")
    print(f"Warning: Generated structure may consume significant inodes, ensure filesystem support")
```
Run the python script.
```shell
python generate_project.py ${path} --files 1000000
```
2.Open project in VS Code with all extensions disabled (code --disable-extensions) 
3.Use file search (Ctrl+P) and sequentially search from 'a' to 'z', observing the memory usage of the extension process.
Expected Behavior:
For file search operations, memory usage should remain within a reasonable range.
Actual Behavior:

Extension Host process memory grows continuously
Memory increases by 1-6GB during search
Process eventually crashes with OOM error after 5-10 letters typed
Heap Dump Analysis Findings:

* Primary memory consumers: Array of objects with structure:
```
{
  base: string,      
  relativePath: string, 
  searchPath: string   
```
* This array grows without bound during search operations
* In the 2G leakage test, an array size exceeding 8 million objects was observed.

Proposed Solution:
Change the data record to a queue with a maximum size of 2 million, and delete any data exceeding this limit.

title: Fix languageId population in editTelemetry.reportEditArc event
body:
The `languageId` field in the `editTelemetry.reportEditArc` telemetry event was empty ~97% of the time because it relied on `data.props.$$languageId` from edit source metadata, which is often not populated.

This change updates the `ChatArcTelemetrySender` class to get the `languageId` directly from the document using `this._document.languageId.get()`, following the same pattern already used successfully in other telemetry events within the same codebase.

**Changes made:**
- Modified `ChatArcTelemetrySender` constructor to accept the document as an additional parameter
- Updated the telemetry event to use `this._document.languageId.get()` instead of `data.props.$$languageId`
- Updated the instantiation in `editSourceTrackingImpl.ts` to pass the document parameter

This approach is consistent with how `languageId` is populated in other telemetry events (lines 210, 254, 297 in `editSourceTrackingImpl.ts`) and ensures the field will now be populated with the actual language name (e.g., "javascript", "typescript", "python") instead of being empty.

Fixes #261334.

title: Support dynamic agent model switching during run (e.g., Sonnet → GPT-5 → Gemini) with prompt forwarding & context sharing

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Right now, once a run starts, it’s locked to one model (Sonnet, GPT-5, Gemini, etc.). If you want to use a different one, you basically have to restart the conversation or lose context.

It would be useful if an agent could switch models *during* a run and keep going without losing state.

For example we can introduce a `tool` `switch_mode` which accepts:
- New agent mode id/ name
- context to pass
- prompt to pass

Offcourse, this also need careful planning of modes, tool should know what mdoels are configures in user environment. 

Example:

* Use **Sonnet** for planning.
* Switch to **GPT-5** for implementation.
* Switch to **Gemini** for verification/ docuemntation.

Jsut like roocode, any agent mode can call tool letys jusr say `switch_mode` to change mode.

body:
### GitHub Tags:
#A11yTCS; #A11ySev2; #Visual Studio Code Client; #BM_Visual Studio Code Client_Win32_JULY2024; #DesktopApp; #Win32; #Benchmark;

### Environment and OS details:
Application Name: Visual Studio Code
Version: 1.104.0-insider (user setup)
OS build :26100.4770  

### Reproduction Steps:

1. Open Visual studio code insider.
2. Tab till code editor 
3. Press Ctrl+ G to go to the desired line.
4. Now press esc key.
5. Observed that After using Ctrl+G to navigate, pressing the Escape key does not return the focus to the current line.

### Actual Result:
After using Ctrl+G to jump to a line, pressing Escape doesn't bring the focus back to the current line; instead, it moves the focus to the first line of the code.

### Expected Result:
When a user presses Ctrl+G, the cursor should move to the specified line and the screen reader should announce the line number. If the user then presses Escape, the keyboard focus should remain on the same line—not jump to the first line of the code.

### User Impact:
Screen reader and keyboard user face difficulty as they have to navigate back again to the desired line.

### Attachment:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4b9ed9b5-9d6b-464d-b07f-e832c4246dd6

title: Default `markdown.updateLinksOnFileMove.enabled` to `true`

labels.name: markdown
labels.description: Markdown support issues

labels.name: *as-designed
labels.description: Described behavior is as designed

body:
`markdown.updateLinksOnFileMove.enabled` was added in https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_73#_markdown-automatic-link-updates-on-file-rename-move.

I think it would make sense to have the default changed to `true`. Otherwise many people miss this great feature and I would _guess_ more want it enabled than not. Like many other "auto-change-paths-on-move" features.

title: [Bug] Copilot Chat shows "Enable shell integration" warning despite correctly configured shell integration in SSH remote environment

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
# GitHub Copilot Bug Report: Shell Integration Warning Persists Despite Correct Configuration

## 🐛 **Bug Description**
The GitHub Copilot Chat interface continuously displays the warning message "Enable shell integration to improve command detection" even when shell integration is properly configured and functioning correctly.

## 📋 **Environment Information**

### System Details
- **OS**: Linux Ubuntu 20.04 (vmi1583678.contaboserver.net)
- **Kernel**: 5.15.0-91-generic #101-Ubuntu SMP Tue Nov 14 13:30:08 UTC 2023 x86_64
- **Shell**: ZSH 5.8.1 with oh-my-zsh
- **VS Code Server**: Remote SSH connection
- **VS Code Version**: 1.103.0 (commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f)

### Extension Versions
- **GitHub Copilot**: v1.350.0 (build 1705)
- **GitHub Copilot Chat**: v0.29.1 (build 1)

### Shell Integration Status
✅ **WORKING CORRECTLY:**
- `TERM_PROGRAM=vscode`
- `VSCODE_SHELL_INTEGRATION=1`
- `VSCODE_INJECTION=1`
- Official VS Code shell integration script loaded via `$(code --locate-shell-integration-path zsh)`

## 🔧 **Configuration Files**

### `.zshrc` Configuration
```bash
# VS Code Shell Integration - Official method
if [[ "$TERM_PROGRAM" == "vscode" ]]; then
    # Load official VS Code script
    source "$(code --locate-shell-integration-path zsh)"
    
    # Force required environment variables
    export VSCODE_SHELL_INTEGRATION=1
    export VSCODE_INJECTION=1
fi
```

### VS Code Global Settings (`/root/.vscode-server/data/User/settings.json`)
```json
{
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.enabled": true,
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.decorationsEnabled": "both",
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.history": 100,
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.suggestEnabled": true,
    "terminal.integrated.enablePersistentSessions": true,
    "terminal.integrated.detectLocale": "auto",
    "terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.linux": "zsh",
    "terminal.integrated.profiles.linux": {
        "zsh": {
            "path": "/usr/bin/zsh",
            "args": ["-l"]
        }
    }
}
```

### Workspace Settings (`.vscode/settings.json`)
```json
{
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.enabled": true,
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.decorationsEnabled": "both",
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.history": 100,
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.suggestEnabled": true,
    "terminal.integrated.enablePersistentSessions": true,
    "terminal.integrated.detectLocale": "auto",
    "github.copilot.enable": {
        "*": true,
        "plaintext": false,
        "markdown": true,
        "scminput": false
    }
}
```

## ✅ **Verification Steps Performed**

1. **Shell Integration Script Loading**:
   ```bash
   $ code --locate-shell-integration-path zsh
   /root/.vscode-server/cli/servers/Stable-e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f/server/out/vs/workbench/contrib/terminal/common/scripts/shellIntegration-rc.zsh
   ```

2. **Environment Variables Check**:
   ```bash
   $ echo $VSCODE_SHELL_INTEGRATION
   1
   $ echo $VSCODE_INJECTION  
   1
   $ echo $TERM_PROGRAM
   vscode
   ```

3. **Command Detection Testing**:
   - Commands are properly detected and tracked ✅
   - Exit codes are captured correctly ✅
   - Directory changes are monitored ✅
   - All shell integration features work as expected ✅

## 🚨 **Expected vs Actual Behavior**

### Expected
- Warning message should disappear when shell integration is properly configured
- Copilot should detect the active shell integration and stop showing the warning

### Actual
- Warning message "Enable shell integration to improve command detection" persists in Copilot Chat interface
- All shell integration functionality works correctly despite the warning
- Message appears to be cosmetic/UI detection issue rather than functional problem

## 🔍 **Investigation Results**

### Code Analysis
- Searched through Copilot extension files for the warning message text
- No hardcoded strings found in `/root/.vscode-server/extensions/github.copilot*/`
- Message appears to be generated dynamically by VS Code core or Copilot runtime
- Likely related to internal API checks rather than configuration files

### Attempted Solutions
1. ✅ Modified `.zshrc` with official shell integration loading
2. ✅ Added global VS Code settings for shell integration
3. ✅ Added workspace-specific settings
4. ✅ Restarted terminals and VS Code server multiple times
5. ✅ Verified all environment variables are set correctly
6. ✅ Tested command detection functionality (working)
7. ✅ Checked extension configurations

## 💭 **Suspected Root Cause**

The issue appears to be a **detection/UI bug** where:
- Copilot Chat interface uses a different detection method than the actual shell integration functionality
- May be related to timing issues in remote SSH environments
- Could be a caching issue in the Copilot extension
- Might be specific to certain VS Code Server versions or remote setups

## 🎯 **Reproduction Steps**

1. Connect to remote Linux server via SSH in VS Code
2. Configure ZSH with oh-my-zsh
3. Add official shell integration configuration to `.zshrc`
4. Set all recommended VS Code settings for shell integration
5. Verify shell integration is working (`VSCODE_SHELL_INTEGRATION=1`)
6. Open Copilot Chat
7. Observe persistent warning message despite functional integration

## 🙏 **Request**

Please investigate why the Copilot Chat interface doesn't recognize properly configured shell integration in remote SSH environments. The warning message is misleading since shell integration is actually working correctly.

## 📋 **Additional Notes**

This appears to be a UI/detection issue rather than a functional problem. All shell integration features work as expected, but the warning message creates confusion and suggests misconfiguration when everything is actually set up correctly.

**Environment Summary:**
- Date: qua 13 ago 2025 00:58:51 -03
- VS Code: 1.103.0 e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f x64
- Shell: /usr/bin/zsh (ZSH_VERSION: 5.8.1)
- All integration variables correctly set

title: Repo name is not displayed in Source Control sidebar

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

labels.name: scm
labels.description: General SCM compound issues

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

body: **Note**: this looks like a regression of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/ed24319ef9264a668ceec8d025c2f37763da8363 See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/e7be6e9cff48691fcea95842998f2101b64463fc#diff-87e0ff1d8aa33251109869f70c4b40afdb62f995035b783765095726c7137118 Since a recent update, the Source Control sidebar no longer displays *any part* of the repo name if the branch name is too long. This is a problem for us since we work with a lot of sub-repos and use the same branch names for each (automatically created from the ticket title, which makes them long). As it stands, VSCode can display several entries with no way to easily differentiate between them, and even if different branch names are used, without seeing the repo name we cannot know if we have the right branch checked out. For example, see the first three lines here: I understand that some people prefer to see the branch while others prefer to see the repo, so why not make it configurable? Or give an option to set a minimum width for the repo field so we can at least see the tooltip on hover. There is no need to choose a side when a configuration option can make everyone happy. Or, you know, just fix the regression :)
